Package Contents

equitorch.utils.check_degree_range(L: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange) → Tuple[int, int]

Check and normalize the degree range.

Parameters:

L (DegreeRange) – The input degree range. Can be an int or a tuple of two ints.

Returns:

A tuple representing the normalized degree range (l_min, l_max).

Return type:

Tuple[int, int]

Example

>>> L = (1, 3)
>>> result = check_degree_range(L)
>>> print(result)
(1, 3)
>>> L = 5
>>> result = check_degree_range(L)
>>> print(result)
(0, 5)
equitorch.utils.degrees_in_range(L: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange)

Returns range(L[0], L[1]+1).

equitorch.utils.get_center_of_mass(pos: torch.Tensor, ptr: torch.Tensor, atom_mass: torch.Tensor | None = None)

Calculate the center of mass for each molecule in a batch.

Parameters:

  • pos (Tensor) – Tensor of shape (N, 3) containing the positions of all atoms.

  • ptr (Tensor) – Tensor containing the cumulative sum of atoms for each molecule in the batch.

  • atom_mass (Tensor, optional) – Tensor of shape (N,) containing the mass of each atom. If None, all atoms are assumed to have equal mass.

Returns:

Tensor of shape (B, 3) containing the center of mass for each molecule in the batch, where B is the number of molecules.

Return type:

Tensor

equitorch.utils.zero_center_of_mass(pos: torch.Tensor, batch: torch.Tensor, center_of_mass: torch.Tensor)

Shift the positions of atoms in each molecule so that their center of mass is at the origin.

Parameters:

  • pos (Tensor) – Tensor of shape (N, 3) containing the positions of all atoms.

  • batch (Tensor) – Tensor of shape (N,) indicating which molecule each atom belongs to.

  • center_of_mass (Tensor) – Tensor of shape (B, 3) containing the center of mass for each molecule, where B is the number of molecules.

Returns:

Tensor of shape (N, 3) containing the shifted positions of all atoms.

Return type:

Tensor

Notes

This function subtracts the center of mass of each molecule from the positions of its atoms, effectively centering each molecule at the origin.

equitorch.utils.align_to_z_mat(r: torch.Tensor, need_normalize: bool = True)

Calculate the rotation matrix R that aligns the vector r with the z-axis.

Parameters:

  • r (Tensor) – Input vector to be aligned.

  • need_normalize (bool, optional) – Whether to normalize the input vector. Default is True.

Returns:

Rotation matrix R such that R @ r = z.

Return type:

Tensor

equitorch.utils.edge_align_to_z_mat(pos: torch.Tensor, edge_index: torch.Tensor)

Calculate the rotation matrix R that aligns the edge vector with the z-axis.

Parameters:

  • pos (Tensor) – Tensor of node positions.

  • edge_index (Tensor) – Tensor of edge indices.

Returns:

Rotation matrix R such that R @ r = z, where r is the edge vector.

Return type:

Tensor

equitorch.utils.edge_align_to_z_angles(pos: torch.Tensor, edge_index: torch.Tensor)

Calculate the angles (phi, theta) that describe the rotation to align an edge vector with the z-axis.

Parameters:

  • pos (Tensor) – Tensor of node positions.

  • edge_index (Tensor) – Tensor of edge indices.

Returns:

A tuple (phi, theta) where: - r can be generated by rotating z on y by theta, and then rotating on z by phi. - r can be aligned to z by rotating on z by -phi, and then on y by -theta.

Return type:

Tuple[Tensor, Tensor]

equitorch.utils.align_to_z_wigner(r: torch.Tensor, L: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, need_normalize: bool = True)

Returns the Wigner-D matrix corresponding to the return of align_to_z_mat.

Parameters:

  • r (Tensor) – Input vector to be aligned.

  • L (DegreeRange) – Range of degrees for the Wigner-D matrix.

  • need_normalize (bool, optional) – Whether to normalize the input vector. Default is True.

Returns:

Wigner-D matrix corresponding to the rotation returned by align_to_z_mat.

Return type:

Tensor

equitorch.utils.edge_align_to_z_wigner(pos: torch.Tensor, edge_index: torch.Tensor, L: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange)

Calculate the Wigner-D matrix corresponding to the rotation that aligns an edge vector with the z-axis.

Parameters:

  • pos (Tensor) – Tensor of node positions.

  • edge_index (Tensor) – Tensor of edge indices.

  • L (DegreeRange) – Range of degrees for the Wigner-D matrix.

Returns:

Wigner-D matrix corresponding to the rotation that aligns the edge vector with the z-axis.

Return type:

Tensor

equitorch.utils.rot_on(mat: torch.Tensor, x: torch.Tensor)

Performs rotation of matrix ‘mat’ on tensor ‘x’.

This function applies the rotation defined by ‘mat’ to the tensor ‘x’. The behavior depends on the dimensions of both ‘mat’ and ‘x’.

Parameters:

  • mat (Tensor) – The rotation matrix or matrices. Can be 2D, 3D, or 4D. - If 2D: A single rotation matrix applied to all samples in x. - If 3D: Batched rotation matrices applied sample-wise to x. - If 4D: Batched rotation matrices applied both sample-wise and channel-wise to x.

  • x (Tensor) – The tensor to be rotated. Can be 2D or 3D. - If 2D: Interpreted as a batch of vectors. - If 3D: Interpreted as a batch of matrices or multi-channel vectors.

Returns:

The rotated tensor. The shape will match the input ‘x’, except when ‘mat’ is 4D, in which case the channel dimension may change.

Return type:

Tensor

Notes

  • If x is 2D, it’s temporarily expanded to 3D for computation and then squeezed back.

  • The function uses matrix multiplication for 2D and 3D ‘mat’, and einsum for 4D ‘mat’.

equitorch.utils.check_degree_range(L: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange) → Tuple[int, int]

Check and normalize the degree range.

Parameters:

L (DegreeRange) – The input degree range. Can be an int or a tuple of two ints.

Returns:

A tuple representing the normalized degree range (l_min, l_max).

Return type:

Tuple[int, int]

Example

>>> L = (1, 3)
>>> result = check_degree_range(L)
>>> print(result)
(1, 3)
>>> L = 5
>>> result = check_degree_range(L)
>>> print(result)
(0, 5)
equitorch.utils.degrees_in_range(L: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange)

Returns range(L[0], L[1]+1).

equitorch.utils.order_batch(L: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, device=None)

Generate a tensor of degree indices for each order.

Parameters:

  • L (DegreeRange) – The degree range.

  • device (torch.device, optional) – The device to place the resulting tensor on.

Returns:

A tensor where each element is the degree index for the corresponding order.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

Example

>>> L = (0, 2)
>>> result = order_batch(L)
>>> print(result)
tensor([0, 1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2])
equitorch.utils.extract_batch_ptr(keys: List[torch.Tensor])

key: sorted, int returns: batch, ptr, key_value

equitorch.utils.order_ptr(L: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, dim: int = 0, device=None)

Generate a tensor of pointers to the start of each degree’s orders, including the next of the final elements.

Parameters:

  • L (DegreeRange) – The degree range.

  • dim (int, optional) – The dimension along which to expand the result. Default is 0.

  • device (torch.device, optional) – The device to place the resulting tensor on.

Returns:

A tensor of pointers to the start of each degree’s orders.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

Example

>>> L = (0, 2)
>>> result = order_ptr(L)
>>> print(result)
tensor([0, 1, 4, 9])
>>> L = (1, 3)
>>> result = order_ptr(L)
>>> print(result)
tensor([0, 3, 8, 15])
equitorch.utils.order_in_degree_range(L: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, zero_based: bool = True, device=None)

Generate a tensor that specifying the order \(m\) in a feature of degree range \(L\).

Parameters:

  • L (DegreeRange) – The degree range.

  • zero_based (bool, optional) – Whether the \(m\) is in \(0,\dots,2l_ ext{max}+1\) or \(-l_ ext{max},\dots,l_ ext{max}\). Default is True.

  • device (torch.device, optional) – The device to place the resulting tensor on.

Returns:

A tensor denoting the degrees.

Return type:

Tensor

Example

>>> L = (1, 2)
>>> result = order_in_degree_range(L, True)
>>> print(result)
tensor([1, 2, 3, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4])
>>> result = order_in_degree_range(L, False)
>>> print(result)
tensor([-1, 0, 1, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2])
equitorch.utils.orders_in_degree(l: int)

returns range(-l, l+1)

equitorch.utils.list_degrees(L: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, L1: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, L2: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange = None, cond: Callable[[int, int, int], bool] | None = None)

Generate a list of valid degree triplets (l, l1, l2). (The triplet satisfies triangular inequality)

Parameters:

  • L (DegreeRange) – The range for the total angular momentum l.

  • L1 (DegreeRange) – The range for the first angular momentum l1.

  • L2 (DegreeRange) – The range for the second angular momentum l2. default: None, represents the range of all possible l2’s

  • cond (Callable[[int, int, int], bool], optional) – An optional condition function to further filter the triplets.

Returns:

A sorted list of valid (l, l1, l2) triplets.

Return type:

List[Tuple[int, int, int]]

Example

>>> print(list_degrees(1, (1,2), (2,3)))
[(0, 2, 2), (1, 1, 2), (1, 2, 2), (1, 2, 3)]
equitorch.utils.num_degree_triplets(L: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, L1: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, L2: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange = None, cond: Callable[[int, int, int], bool] | None = None)

Generate the number of valid degree triplets (l, l1, l2). (The triplet satisfies triangular inequality)

Parameters:

  • L (DegreeRange) – The range for the total angular momentum l.

  • L1 (DegreeRange) – The range for the first angular momentum l1.

  • L2 (DegreeRange) – The range for the second angular momentum l2.

  • cond (Callable[[int, int, int], bool], optional) – An optional condition function to further filter the triplets.

Returns:

The number of valid degree triplets.

Return type:

int

Example

>>> print(num_degree_triplets(1, (1,2), (2,3)))
4

  • lmax (int) – The maximum degree.

Returns:

The total number of orders between lmin and lmax (inclusive).

int

Calculate the number of orders for a given degree.

Parameters:

l (int) – The degree.

Returns:

The number of orders for the given degree (2l + 1).

Return type:

int

equitorch.utils.degree_index_from(l: int, l_min: int)

Calculate the start and end indices for a given degree.

Parameters:

  • l (int) – The degree.

  • l_min (int) – The minimum degree in the range.

Returns:

A tuple containing the start and end indices for the given degree.

Return type:

Tuple[int, int]

Example

>>> l, l_min = 2, 0
>>> result = degree_index_from(l, l_min)
>>> print(result)
(4, 8)
equitorch.utils.degree_order_to_index(l, m, l_min=0)

Convert degree and order to a linear index.

Parameters:

  • l (int) – The degree.

  • m (int) – The order.

  • l_min (int, optional) – The minimum degree in the range. Default is 0.

Returns:

The linear index corresponding to the given degree and order.

Return type:

int

Example

>>> l, m, l_min = 2, 1, 0
>>> result = degree_order_to_index(l, m, l_min)
>>> print(result)
7

  • L (DegreeRange) – The degree range.

  • dim (int) – The dimension along which to expand the tensor.

Returns:

torch.Tensor

equitorch.utils.degree_order_to_index(l, m, l_min=0)

Convert degree and order to a linear index.

Parameters:

  • l (int) – The degree.

  • m (int) – The order.

int

Example

>>> l, m, l_min = 2, 1, 0
>>> result = degree_order_to_index(l, m, l_min)
>>> print(result)

equitorch.utils.degrees_in_range(L: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange)

equitorch.utils.dense_CG(L: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, L1: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, L2: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, condition: Callable | None = None, dtype=torch.float)[source]

Generate dense Clebsch-Gordan (CG) matrices for given angular momentum ranges.

This function computes the Clebsch-Gordan coefficients for coupling two angular momenta \(l_1\) and \(l_2\) to a total angular momentum \(l\). The coefficients are organized into a dense matrix format.

Parameters:

  • L (DegreeRange) – Range of total angular momentum \(l\).

  • L1 (DegreeRange) – Range of first angular momentum \(l_1\).

  • L2 (DegreeRange) – Range of second angular momentum \(l_2\).

  • condition (callable, optional) – A function that takes \((l, l_1, l_2)\) as arguments and returns a boolean or float. If provided, it is used to filter the CG coefficients.

  • dtype (torch.dtype, optional) – The desired data type of the output tensor. Default is torch.float.

Returns:

A dense tensor of Clebsch-Gordan coefficients. The shape of the tensor is \((l_{max}^2 - l_{min}^2,l_{1,max}^2 - l_{1,min}^2, l_{2,max}^2 - l_{2,min}^2)\).

Return type:

torch.Tensor

equitorch.utils.blocked_CG(L: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, L1: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, L2: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, condition: Callable | None = None, dtype=torch.float)[source]

Generate blocked Clebsch-Gordan (CG) coefficients for given angular momentum ranges.

This function computes the Clebsch-Gordan coefficients for coupling two angular momenta \(l_1\) and \(l_2\) to a total angular momentum \(l\). The coefficients are organized into a dictionary of tensors, where each tensor corresponds to a specific \((l, l_1, l_2)\) combination.

Parameters:

  • L (DegreeRange) – Range of total angular momentum \(l\).

  • L1 (DegreeRange) – Range of first angular momentum \(l_1\).

  • L2 (DegreeRange) – Range of second angular momentum \(l_2\).

  • condition (callable, optional) – A function that takes \((l, l_1, l_2)\) as arguments and returns a boolean. If provided, it is used to filter the CG coefficients.

  • dtype (torch.dtype, optional) – The desired data type of the output tensors. Default is torch.float.

Returns:

A dictionary where each key is a tuple \((l, l_1, l_2)\), and each value is a tensor of Clebsch-Gordan coefficients for that combination.

Return type:

Dict[Tuple[int, int, int], torch.Tensor]

equitorch.utils.coo_CG(L: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, L1: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, L2: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, condition: Callable | None = None, dtype=torch.float, device=None)[source]

Generate sparse Clebsch-Gordan (CG) coefficients in coordinate format.

This function computes the non-zero Clebsch-Gordan coefficients for coupling two angular momenta \(l_1\) and \(l_2\) to a total angular momentum \(l\), and returns them in a sparse format. The results are sorted in the order of (l, M, l1, l2, M1, M2).

Parameters:

  • L (DegreeRange) – Range of total angular momentum \(l\).

  • L1 (DegreeRange) – Range of first angular momentum \(l_1\).

  • L2 (DegreeRange) – Range of second angular momentum \(l_2\).

  • condition (callable, optional) – A function that takes \((l, l_1, l_2)\) as arguments and returns a boolean. If provided, it is used to filter the CG coefficients.

  • dtype (torch.dtype, optional) – The desired data type of the output tensors. Default is torch.float.

  • device (torch.device, optional) – The desired device of the output tensors. Default is None (uses current device).

Returns:

A tuple containing:

  • CsTensor of shape (N,)

    Non-zero CG coefficient values.

  • MsTensor of shape (3, N)

    Indices (M, M1, M2) of non-zero CG values.

  • ls_cgTensor of shape (3, N)

    Corresponding degrees (l, l1, l2) for each non-zero CG value.

  • l_indTensor of shape (N,)

    Indices of (l, l1, l2) combinations.

Where N is the number of non-zero CG coefficients.

Return type:

Tuple[Tensor, Tensor, Tensor, Tensor]

Notes

  • The output is strictly sorted in the order of (l, M, l1, l2, M1, M2) lexigraphically.

equitorch.utils.blocked_CG(L: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, L1: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, L2: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, condition: Callable | None = None, dtype=torch.float)[source]

Generate blocked Clebsch-Gordan (CG) coefficients for given angular momentum ranges.

This function computes the Clebsch-Gordan coefficients for coupling two angular momenta \(l_1\) and \(l_2\) to a total angular momentum \(l\). The coefficients are organized into a dictionary of tensors, where each tensor corresponds to a specific \((l, l_1, l_2)\) combination.

Parameters:

  • L (DegreeRange) – Range of total angular momentum \(l\).

  • L1 (DegreeRange) – Range of first angular momentum \(l_1\).

  • L2 (DegreeRange) – Range of second angular momentum \(l_2\).

  • condition (callable, optional) – A function that takes \((l, l_1, l_2)\) as arguments and returns a boolean. If provided, it is used to filter the CG coefficients.

  • dtype (torch.dtype, optional) – The desired data type of the output tensors. Default is torch.float.

Returns:

A dictionary where each key is a tuple \((l, l_1, l_2)\), and each value is a tensor of Clebsch-Gordan coefficients for that combination.

Return type:

Dict[Tuple[int, int, int], torch.Tensor]

equitorch.utils.so3_weights_to_so2(weight_so3: torch.Tensor, L_in: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, L_out: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, channel_wise=True)[source]

Transform the weights used for SO3Linear to the weights for SO2Linear.

Parameters:

  • weight_so3 (torch.Tensor) – The weights used for SO3Linear. Shape depends on channel_wise: - If not channel_wise: \((N, ext{num_degree_in}, ext{in_channels}, ext{out_channels})\) or \(( ext{num_degree_in}, ext{in_channels}, ext{out_channels})\) - If channel_wise: \((N, ext{num_degree_in}, ext{channels})\) or \(( ext{num_degree_in}, ext{channels})\) It should be sorted by \((l_ ext{out}, l_ ext{in}, l_ ext{edge})\) lexicographically in the num_degree_in dimension. \(l_ ext{edge}\) should take all values from \(|l_ ext{out}-l_ ext{in}|\) to \(l_ ext{out}+l_ ext{in}\) for a given pair of \(l_ ext{out}\) and \(l_ ext{in}\).

  • L_in (DegreeRange) – The degree range of input features.

  • L_out (DegreeRange) – The degree range of output features.

  • channel_wise (bool, optional) – Whether the weights are channel-wise. Default is True.

Returns:

weight_so2 – Transformed weights for SO2Linear, with the same shape as weight_so3, sorted by \((l_ ext{out}, l_ ext{in}, m)\) lexicographically in the num_degree_in dimension.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

equitorch.utils.so2_weights_to_so3(weight_so2: torch.Tensor, L_in: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, L_out: equitorch.typing.DegreeRange, channel_wise=True)[source]

Transform the weights used for SO2Linear to the weights for SO3Linear.

Parameters:

  • weight_so2 (torch.Tensor) – The weights used for SO2Linear. Shape depends on channel_wise: - If not channel_wise: \((N, ext{num_degree_in}, ext{in_channels}, ext{out_channels})\) or \(( ext{num_degree_in}, ext{in_channels}, ext{out_channels})\) - If channel_wise: \((N, ext{num_degree_in}, ext{channels})\) or \(( ext{num_degree_in}, ext{channels})\) It should be sorted by \((l_ ext{out}, l_ ext{in}, m)\) lexicographically in the num_degree_in dimension.

  • L_in (DegreeRange) – The degree range of input features.

  • L_out (DegreeRange) – The degree range of output features.

  • channel_wise (bool, optional) – Whether the weights are channel-wise. Default is True.

Returns:

weight_so3 – Transformed weights for SO3Linear, with the same shape as weight_so2, sorted by \((l_ ext{out}, l_ ext{in}, l_ ext{edge})\) lexicographically in the num_degree_in dimension. \(l_ ext{edge}\) will take all values from \(|l_ ext{out}-l_ ext{in}|\) to \(l_ ext{out}+l_ ext{in}\) for a given pair of \(l_ ext{out}\) and \(l_ ext{in}\).

Return type:

torch.Tensor
